title: HSS throws another spanner in the works with profit warning
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Aug 26, 2015, 09:52 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 38 mins HSS throws another spanner in the works with profit warning By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago 41.08 -0.21 
The tool hire company, which told investors in June that it would miss expectations, disappoints again by warning full-year earnings will be below forecasts on the back of "unpredictable trading" 
HSS has issued another profit warning after suffering "unpredictable" trading in the first six months of the year. 
Sales growth for the full year is now expected to range from 8 to 11pc, while profit will fall below City forecasts, chief executive Chris Davies said. 
"As others have reported, trading continues to be unpredictable, and after a reasonable July, we have seen softer market conditions in August," he added. 
"This is obviously disappointing. As a result we are cautious on the outlook for the balance of the year." 
The announcement came as the group, which had a lacklustre debut on London’s stock market in February , unveiled its first-half results. 
The figures were in line with what City analysts had been expecting, although these forecasts had already been revised down in June when management warned that second quarter trading was below expectations . 
Adjusted cash profit, which excludes interest, tax, depreciation, amortisation and exceptional costs, fell flat at £28.9m in the six months to the end of June. 
However, pre-tax losses widened to £14.1m, compared to £11.1m the year before, despite a 12pc rise in sales to £146.4m. 
Still, HSS said that its strategy to gain market share was working well and that it was making progress with plans to open a new distribution centre next year, which it hopes will increase tool equipment availability. 
The company also plans to cut costs by between £8m and £12m next year, with up to £3m in the final quarter of this year. 
The group, which is still partially owned by private equity firm Exponent (NasdaqGS: EXPO - news ) , said that it was “assessing further cost saving opportunities” through refinancing its existing debt facilities next year. 
HSS has been passed through a succession of private equity owners over the years. The company had been in the hands of 3i from 2003 to 2007 before passing to a fund led by City grandee Archie Norman. Inl 2012 it was taken over by Exponent. 
The company is worth £199m and has lost nearly 40pc of its value since listing on the stock market six months ago .
